title.narrative: Guatemala TA

description.narrative: On April 20, Guatemalas CVO sent a letter to APHIS requesting technical assistance in providing Guatemala with CSF vaccines, training and diagnostic support for their CSF control and eradication program. In response, APHIS (having obtained Guatemalas concurrence) sent a group of VS experts from September 17-21, 2012 to evaluate the technical aspects of GUAs CSF program and their eradication and control efforts. The results of this technical visit will help APHIS determine the best course of action in assisting Guatemala with its CSF situation and allow APHIS to assess the feasibility of providing US CSF vaccines for Guatemalas control and eradication program.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Workshop

description.narrative: A Packing House and Post Harvest Inspection Training Workshop was conducted in Santa Cruz del Quiche, Guatemala from December 10-13th. Many crops are lost post harvest due to failure to meet SPS trade standards, either at U.S. ports of entry or regionally. This training focused on high altitude crops that are grown in the western highlands. Much of the workshop was coordinated UC Davis' Marita Cantwell, who is an expert in post-harvest losses. Luis Caniz from APHIS/Guatemala discussed many of the reasons produce is rejected and methods of preventing future rejections. Objective of Program/Visit: The purpose of this training is to decrease post-harvest crop losses for producers, both regionally and at U.S. ports of entry, by improving SPS inspection standards of packing houses and producers

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Plant and post-harvest protection and pest control

title.narrative: Borlaug Fellowship Program

description.narrative: The Borlaug Fellowship Program promotes food security and economic growth by providing training and collaborative research opportunities to fellows from developing and middle-income countries.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

Foreign Agricultural Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Food for Progress

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.

title.narrative: McGovern-Dole Program

description.narrative: The McGovern-Dole program provides for the donation of agricultural commodities and the provision of financial and technical assistance to improve the education, food security and health of school-age children, especially girls, in developing countries.

title.narrative: Micronutrient-fortified Food Aid Products Pilot Program

description.narrative: The Micronutrient-Fortified Food Aid Products Pilot (MFFAPP) is administered under the McGovern-Dole Program. Under MFFAPP, participants will develop and field test new or improved micronutrient-fortified food aid products designed to meet the energy and nutrient needs of populations served by McGovern-Dole Program. Through this effort, USDA hopes to identify new products that would be readily available for distribution through the McGovern-Dole Program

title.narrative: Micronutrient-fortified Food Aid Products Pilot Program

description.narrative: The Micronutrient-Fortified Food Aid Products Pilot (MFFAPP) is administered under the McGovern-Dole Program. Under MFFAPP, participants will develop and field test new or improved micronutrient-fortified food aid products designed to meet the energy and nutrient needs of populations served by McGovern-Dole Program. Through this effort, USDA hopes to identify new products that would be readily available for distribution through the McGovern-Dole Program

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Food for Progress

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Scientific Cooperation Research Program - Mycotoxin Levels Survey

description.narrative: The Scientific Cooperation Research Program supports joint research, extension, and education projects lasting up to two years among domestic and international agricultural professionals. These projects address issues including agricultural trade and market access, animal and plant health, biotechnology, food safety and security, and sustainable natural resource management.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Foreign Agricultural Service, Salaries and Expenses
Foreign Agricultural Service, Salaries and Expenses
Commodity Credit Corporation Fund

title.narrative: Local and Regional Food Aid Procurement Pilot Project

description.narrative: The Local and Regional Food Aid Procurement Project (USDA LRP Project) was authorized as a pilot program under the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (Farm Bill). The primary purpose of the USDA LRP Project is to examine the timeliness and efficiency of local and regional procurement (LRP) as a tool to enhance USG food assistance programs.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program Grants

title.narrative: Scientific Cooperation Research Program - Graine Silos

description.narrative: The Scientific Cooperation Research Program supports joint research, extension, and education projects lasting up to two years among domestic and international agricultural professionals. These projects address issues including agricultural trade and market access, animal and plant health, biotechnology, food safety and security, and sustainable natural resource management.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles
